title: Stock Futures Slip Ahead of Fed Minutes; Investors hope the Federal Reserve's meeting minutes will provide new insight into officials' expectations for future interest-rate increases
text:
Stocks have mounted a furious climb higher recently as investors reassessed expectations that inflation and an economic slowdown could keep share prices falling this year. The S&P 500 has jumped 17% from its June low as investors have reshuffled portfolios and scrambled to cover bearish wagers.

A series of strong earnings reports, as well as data last week showing U.S. inflation eased in July, have spurred much of the recent optimism. Lowe's shares inched higher premarket after it reported quarterly earnings, following strong results Tuesday from Walmart and Home Depot. U.S. retail sales data are also due before the opening bell. Later Wednesday, earnings are due from companies including Cisco Systems and Bath & Body Works.

Minutes from the Fed's recent meeting, due at 2 p.m. ET, could offer more details about the pace of future interest-rate increases. Federal-funds futures, used by traders to place bets on the course of rates, showed investors on Wednesday were pricing in a 57% chance that the Fed will raise rates by 0.75 percentage point in September, according to CME Group. That marked an increase from a 41% chance the day before.

"We're all waiting for the Fed minutes," said Florian Ielpo, head of macro at Lombard Odier Investment Managers. "Like everyone, I'm scratching my head about whether we are experiencing the comeback of a bull market, or if it is just a bear-market rally."

More hawkish signals from the Fed's minutes could pause the stock market's recent rally, investors say.

In commodities, oil prices fell in choppy trading as fears of a global economic slowdown continue to hang over investors. Brent crude, the international oil benchmark, recently fell 0.4% to $91.96 a barrel, extending its declines into a fourth day.

Yields on government bonds moved higher. The yield on the benchmark 10-year U.S. Treasury note rose to 2.886%, from 2.822% Tuesday. Yields rise when bond prices decline. Meanwhile, the yield on the 2-year note rose to 3.333%, from 3.249%, keeping the yield curve inverted. That bond-market signal has historically been considered a key recession predictor.

Ahead of the opening bell in New York, shares of Bed Bath & Beyond jumped 22% as individual investors continued to pile into the stock. Its shares have risen more than 300% in August alone.

Overseas, European stock indexes mostly fell. The pan-continental Stoxx Europe 600 lost 0.5%, while the U.K.'s FTSE 100 lost 0.4%. The U.K.'s Office for National Statistics said Wednesday that consumer prices were 10.1% higher in July than the year before, up from 9.4% in June. Investors sold U.K. government bonds, reflecting expectations that the Bank of England will need to further raise interest rates to tame inflation. The British pound fell 0.1% against the dollar.

In Asia, stocks moved higher. Hong Kong's Hang Seng gained 0.5%, China's Shanghai Composite rose 0.4% and Japan's Nikkei 225 jumped 1.2%.

Stock Futures Slip Ahead of Fed Minutes
